articles.title: The Story of Web Framework Hono, By Its Creator
articles.description: Hono is a neat, lightweight framework designed to run on any JavaScript runtime that has been picking up steam in the past year. You can create a simple app reminiscent of Express.js, say, but run it on Cloudflare Workers, Deno, Bun, or Node. It‚Äôs in heavy use all over the place, and has lots of interesting features like letting you write HTML with JSX.
articles.author: Yusuke Wada

articles.title: Node v23.0.0 (Current) Released
articles.description: Say hello to the newest release line of Node.js that gets all the cutting edge features first (Node 22 will soon become an LTS release as per the usual schedule). Node v23 notably enables support for loading ES modules with require() by default, drops 32-bit Windows support, and node --run goes stable.
articles.author: Rafael Gonzaga

articles.title: JS0/JSSugar: 'The Tooling Will Continue Until Morale Improves'
articles.description: In a rather quirky slidedeck presented at TC39 recently, an idea was floated to call the language JS engines implement ‚ÄòJS0‚Äô and a myriad of features that have to be compiled to JS0 ‚ÄòJSSugar‚Äô. It might not surprise you that this idea is considered.. controversial and ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Theo Browne did a 25-minute video digging into it further.
articles.author: Caolan

articles.title: How to Build an Image Search App with CLIP, Postgres & JavaScript
articles.description: A tutorial that brings together a lot of ideas in one place. CLIP is used to turn images into text descriptions. Postgres is used as a vector database. JavaScript provides the glue for both the frontend (with React) and backend (Node.js).
articles.author: Haziqa Sajid

articles.title: Using Sibling Parameters as Default Values in Functions
articles.description: function myFunc(arg1, arg2 = arg1)? A technique safely in the ‚Äònot a lot of people know you can do that‚Äô pile. Alex digs into it a bit and looks at some use cases.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: Liskov's Gun: The Parallel Evolution of React and Web Components
articles.description: An opinion piece so long there‚Äôs an EPUB version. Baldur tackles Web Components, their growing pains, why frameworks like React took a different path, and why the whole topic remains a difficult circle to square.
articles.author: Baldur Bjarnason

articles.title: React Folder Structure in Five Steps, 2024 Edition
articles.description: Articles about structuring React apps are always popular; this one breaks the idea down to five steps from the simplest of apps to more complex ones. Bulletproof React is worth a look too for something broader.
articles.author: Robin Wieruch

articles.title: ApexCharts: Flexible Interactive Charting Library
articles.description: A mature and frequently updated charting library for creating interactive data visualizations, with sparklines, heatmaps, line charts, funnel charts, pies, and others. Can be used in a vanilla way or alongside Angular, Vue or React and there are lots of live examples (with code for each). GitHub repo.
articles.author: ApexCharts

articles.title: Over 100 Algorithms and Data Structures Demonstrated in JS
articles.description: Examples of numerous common algorithms (e.g. bit manipulation, Pascal‚Äôs triangle, Hamming distance) and data structures (e.g. linked lists, tries, graphs) with explanations.
articles.author: Oleksii Trekhleb et al.

articles.title: fast-grid: The World's Most Performant DOM-Based Web Table?
articles.description: A bold claim, but you can see for yourself using the online demo, which lets you filter, sort, and scroll simultaneously for a true test.
articles.author: Gabriel Petersson

articles.title: üé®¬†Color Thief: Grab Color Palettes from Images
articles.description: Given an image, this uses canvas to return a list of the dominant colors. Works in browsers or Node.
articles.author: Lokesh Dhakar

articles.title: Node Version Manager Desktop 4.0
articles.description: A Tauri-powered desktop app for macOS, Windows and Linux to manage multiple installed versions of Node on your system.
articles.author: rainbow

articles.title: üéπ¬†ChordSymbol: Chord Symbol Parser and Renderer
articles.description: Accepts chord names in strings (e.g. G7/B, Cadd9, Asus2) and lets you access the notes those chords are made of. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Christophe No√´l

articles.description: Greensock's popular JavaScript animation library GSAP has been acquired by Webflow ‚Äì it'll continue to be updated and maintained as before.
Did you know setTimeout struggles to set timeouts longer than 25 days (or 2^31 milliseconds) in duration? Never fear: Evan Hahn unveils setBigTimeout.
quickjs-cross-compiler provides a way to generate static binaries of JavaScript apps for x86_64, i686, ARM 7, and ARM64.
Electron 33 ‚Äì The popular way to build cross-platform desktop apps gets a bump up to Chromium 30, Node 20.18, V8 13, but drops macOS 10.15 support.
Wasp 0.15 ‚Äì Wasp is a Rails-like framework using Node, React & Prisma.
Zustand 5.0 ‚Äì Simple, flux-inspired state management for React.
Javet 4.0 ‚Äì Java + V8. Embed Node.js and V8 into Java.
Next.js 15 Release Candidate 2, Node.js 22.10.0 (Current), Jasmine 5.4

articles.title: The Proposed Interop 2025 Focus Areas
articles.description: A few weeks back we mentioned how ideas and proposals were being sought for Interop 2025. You can now look over all of the ideas put forward, share your feedback, and upvote those you like the look of. Here's how the full proposal selection process works, with the chosen priorities announced next February.
articles.author: web platform tests

articles.title: HTML for People
articles.description: An approachable, friendly set of teachings around creating HTML pages, going from the basics, to adding style, getting things online, and exploring reusable components too. It‚Äôs a well presented, understandable starter guide of sorts ‚Äî  a good one to share with any beginner.
articles.author: Blake Watson beginner

articles.title: 'I‚Äôve Been Doing Blockquotes Wrong'
articles.description: If you skipped past HTML for People above because you‚Äôre an HTML expert, Michelle‚Äôs moment of reflection around the blockquote element might make you pause for thought. HTML is hard, she notes, not least because it‚Äôs both easy and relatively safe to write bad HTML (unlike with bad JavaScript).
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: An Abridged History of Safari Showstoppers
articles.description: The ‚Äòreceipts‚Äô to prove that Safari on iOS is ‚Äúan inconvenience for developers‚Äù and ‚Äúthe fundamental reason interoperability has been stymied in mobile ecosystems‚Äù. Uh-oh, we're getting flashbacks to the IE6 days..
articles.author: Roderick E.J.H. Gadellaa

articles.title: Why GOV.UK‚Äôs 'Exit This Page' Component Doesn‚Äôt Use the 'Escape' Key
articles.description: The considerations behind a relatively straightforward component: a big red button that sticks to the top of the screen. If you click it, you‚Äôre quickly taken away from the page you‚Äôre viewing to something inconspicuous.
articles.author: Kim 'beeps' Grey

articles.title: WordPress Drama Explained (and How it May Affect Your Site)
articles.description: Yep, this is still a thing. In fact, #wpdrama is trending on X as we write. Beyond some mud slinging (and disappearing blog posts), the biggest news is likely the forced removal of the Advanced Custom Fields plugin from the WordPress directory.
articles.author: Syed Balkhi

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Drawing a Clay Character with CSS
articles.description: A roughly 15 minute video tutorial that touches upon CSS positioning, masks, clip-path, custom properties, and more. The source code / demo is on Codepen.
articles.author: Alvaro Montoro

articles.title: .io Domain Likely Being Phased-out? Seven Suggested Steps
articles.description: I‚Äôm still not wholly convinced this will actually happen (wishful thinking?), but it‚Äôs still a good idea to be prepared for that possible eventuality.
articles.author: Tantek

articles.title: On the Web, and Optimism
articles.description: ‚ÄúI feel we‚Äôve perhaps learned some painful lessons, become less naive. And on this more realistic foundation, there‚Äôs a chance to build things differently this time‚Äù.
articles.author: John Allsopp

articles.title: Creating Blogs with Astro
articles.description: How to use the popular Astro content site framework to create a full-featured blog.
articles.author: Matt Scarpino

articles.title: Build a Static RSS Reader to Fight Your Inner FOMO
articles.description: A look at creating a basic daily updating RSS feed reader with Astro.
articles.author: Karin Hendrikse

articles.title: Motion Canvas: Create Dynamic Canvas-Rendered Animations
articles.description: There‚Äôs two parts. A library where you use generator functions to procedurally define animations, and an editor that provides a real-time preview of said animations which you can see in action here.
articles.author: Motion Canvas

articles.title: fast-grid: The 'World's Most Performant' DOM-Based Web Table
articles.description: A bold claim for sure, but you can see for yourself using the online demo, which lets you filter, sort, and scroll simultaneously for a true test.
articles.author: Gabriel Petersson

articles.title: balloons-js: An Animated Balloons Effect for Your Site
articles.description: Try it here. Definitely needs a plugin that lets you ‚Äúpop‚Äù the balloons with mouse clicks!
articles.author: Artur Bie≈Ñ

articles.title: STDF: Mobile Web Component Library Built with Svelte &¬†Tailwind
articles.description: Based on the standard Web Components API and includes various components for layout, navigation, data-based, info display, feedback, and some other typical options.
articles.author: DUFU

articles.title: Color Thief: Grab Color Palettes from Images in JavaScript
articles.description: Given an image, this uses canvas to return a list of the dominant colors.
articles.author: Lokesh Dhakar
